text:
Share Parts of Australia set to sizzle as record-breaking heatwave blazes on - Yahoo7 Parts of our nation remain in the grip of a ferocious heatwave that’s set to continue Saturday with the eastern seaboard continuing to get hotter than hot, with no relief in sight. Close Catastrophic fire conditions threaten NSW UP NEXT VIDEO Catastrophic fire conditions threaten NSW Catastrophic fire conditions threaten NSW 
As Sydney sweltered through record-breaking temperatures on Friday, Saturday is expected to be equally blistering and even hotter in some parts, as the seemingly never-ending heatwave is set to continue. NSW could experience its hottest February day on record this weekend. Source: BOM. A potential "catastrophic" fire danger warning on Sunday around the Hunter, from the coast, mid-north coast, out through the Central Tablelands, the top end of the greater Sydney region and out to the central west. Source: BOM. Hottest February day at #Sydney Airport today reaching 42.9C at 2:24pm, breaking previous record of 42.6C set on 21 Feb 1980. #heatwave — BOM New South Wales (@BOM_NSW) February 10, 2017 
Sydney will get no relief over the weekend with the city forecast to reach a scorching 39C on Saturday, and the west to reach the mid-40s. 
According to the weather bureau Penrith will reach 46C on Saturday with NSW expected to experience its hottest February day on record this weekend with emergency services staying on high alert for catastrophic fire conditions. 
A state-wide total fire ban has been declared for Saturday as the mercury soars well past 40C in many parts of the state. 
"If you're a little bit inland from the coast in Sydney or the Hunter district, you'll experience probably mid-40s," senior forecaster at the Bureau of Meteorology Andrew Haigh told AAP. 
"That goes for anywhere west of the ranges as well." 
The state's northwest will cop the brunt of the extreme heat with Wilcannia, Ivanhoe, Bourke and Menindee forecast to reach 47C on Saturday. Parts of NSW, the ACT and Queensland are bracing for another round of record-breaking hot weather. Picture: AAP An image taken in Sydney overnight. Source: Instagram Close Sporting events called off as Sydney swelters UP NEXT VIDEO Sporting events called off as Sydney swelters. Source: 7 News Sporting events called off as Sydney swelters 
In the Hunter region, Singleton and Cessnock are predicted to reach 46C and 43C on Sunday. 
The Rural Fire Service has warned of a potential "catastrophic" fire danger warning on Sunday largely around the Hunter, from the coast, mid-north coast, out through the Central Tablelands, the top end of the greater Sydney region and out to the central west. 
The RFS has urged residents to have their bushfire survival plans ready. 
The sizzling conditions will also continue to push the state's energy network to limit with demand for power among the highest on record. 
NSW managed to dodge widespread power blackouts on Friday despite demand reaching unprecedented levels as temperatures reached 45C in western Sydney and 47.4C in the western Riverina town of Hay. 
The stress on the system will persist over the weekend, the Australian Market Energy Operator says, and it's warned residents to be mindful of their electricity use. The NSW Energy Minister had earlier urged residents to go out to the movies or a local shopping centre to escape the heat, in a bid to reduce electricity usage. Source: Instagram A monster heatwave is gripping parts of Australia. Source: BOM. — BOM New South Wales (@BOM_NSW) February 10, 2017 
Saturday's Randwick Racecourse races have been postponed to Monday due to concerns about the welfare of horses and riders. 
Health experts are reminding people to stay hydrated, wear sunscreen and look out for people most at risk, while NSW clubs say they will provide water and respite for vulnerable people. 
The nation's capital is also set to swelter this weekend, with Canberra set to reach a woeful 41C on Saturday before a small chance of afternoon storms could possibly cool things off. 
Queensland is also set to swelter with Brisbane expected to reach a top of 36C on Saturday and 39C on Sunday, with many parts of the state expected to exceed 40C. 
Heat records could tumble over the weekend, with the state's hottest February day a possibility of being broken. Close Queensland offers surplus power to eastern states as heatwave hits UP NEXT VIDEO Queensland offers surplus power to eastern states as heatwave hits. Source: 7 News Queensland offers surplus power to eastern states as heatwave hits The heatwave is set to continue over 'Sunny Queensland'. Source: Instagram 
The mercury is expected to reach 46C in Birdsville on Saturday and Sunday, nudging the town's February heat record of 46.2C and the Queensland record of 46.5C. 
The sweltering conditions are set to push temperatures 10C past the February average, with paramedics urging people to keep hydrated to avoid becoming ill. 
They've suggested swapping caffeinated drinks for water, eating small and regular meals and wearing light-coloured cotton clothing. 
"Heat-related illnesses have the potential to be life-threatening and may include heat stroke," Queensland Ambulance Service spokesman Lachlan Parker said. 
Those planning to crank-up the air-conditioning have been assured they can rely on Queensland's power network, which was used to help NSW meet its power needs on Friday. 
"We have confidence in the Queensland power system, which is very robust," Queensland Energy Minister Mark Bailey said. 
Relief from the heat isn't expected until Tuesday following the arrival of a southerly change and from the southwest. Close Students rushed to hospital suffering heat stroke UP NEXT VIDEO Students rushed to hospital suffering heat stroke. Source: 7 News Students rushed to hospital suffering heat stroke Power supplies tipped to be at capacity across the country as sweaty Aussies crank up the air conditioning and fans to combat the heatwave. Picture: AAP 
Luckily for South Australia relief from the seemingly never-ending heatwave has come at long last, however the state's energy woes are likely to persist with no immediate solution to boosting the reliability of electricity supply. 
Adelaide and most of the state sweltered through another scorcher on Friday with the city hitting 40C and some regional centres pushing above 46C after similar highs on Wednesday and Thursday. 
The state avoided blackouts for a second day in a row as the Bureau of Meteorology forecast slightly milder conditions for Saturday ahead of a more significant cool change on Sunday. 
However, the south-westerly winds that will blow through the state will do nothing to cool the debate over the state's energy crisis. 
The federal government continues to blame SA's heavy reliance on renewables, which it says has left the electricity network wanting following the closure of the state's last coal-fired power station last year. Close Brawl at Brighton jetty as South Australia swelters through another hot day UP NEXT VIDEO Brawl at Brighton jetty as South Australia swelters through another hot day Australians have cooled down in a variety of ways during the heatwave today. Photo: @rockfish_catamarans/ Instagram 
But state Energy Minister Tom Koutsantonis says its the rules and mismanagement of the electricity market that's the problem and not the availability of power. 
His government has vowed to go it alone and will detail its plans for "dramatic" intervention in the coming weeks. 
When temperatures first soared in Adelaide on Wednesday about 90,000 consumers across the city and regional SA were unplugged as the Australian Energy Market Operator ordered load shedding to avoid damage to the network. 
A similar situation was avoided the following night with extra gas generation in SA brought online. 
Meanwhile, parts of Perth have been experienced heavy rainfall on Friday which has accompanied what is set to possibly be the coldest February day on record. To combat the heat the following advice has been issued by state authorities. Stay well hydrated Avoid alcohol and hot or sugary drinks Limit physical activity Stay out of the sun during the hottest part of the day Never leave children or pets shut in the car Close
